Click Submit if you are satisfied with your answers or Cancel if you wish to change an answer before moving on.\n\nOnce you click Submit, you will not be able to change a previous answer.
Many cities and towns are encouraging people to use bicycles by putting bike lanes on streets.
A well-designed bike lane allows bikes and cars to share a road safely.
A poorly designed bike lane can be dangerous.
In this task, you will choose the best locations for bike lanes to connect Pleasant Valley and Rolling Hills Park.\n\nYou will consider the following factors.
Which route is the least expensive?
The safety of a street for bicyclists is affected by car lane width and car speed.
Streets are classified into three categories indicating safety for bicyclists.
The street is considered safe for bicyclists.
Certain streets are sometimes safe for bicyclists, but not always. This is because of truck traffic on these streets at certain times of day.
The street is considered unsafe for bicyclists.
Use the two sliders on the left to see how changing the car speed and car lane width affect the safety of a road.\n\nUse the sliders to perform the following.
Change the car's speed limit to 25 mph by using the Speed Limit slider
Select 14 feet of car lane width by using the Car Lane Width slider
When you are finished, click Submit.
Is this combination of speed limit and car lane width considered safe for bicycling?

Use the sliders to help you fill in the table below. Adjusting the speed and width will allow you to see each combination in the table.\n\nWhen you are finished, click Next.

Explain how the combination of lane width and speed limit affects the safety of a bike lane. Support your answer with information from the table on the left.\n\nType your answer in the box below. Then click Submit.

The shortest route (route XGHJ) connecting Pleasant Valley and Rolling Hills Park is shown on the map on the left. The total route length is shown below the map.

Each street along the route has a lane width and speed limit.

The combination of those two factors affects the safety of that street for bicyclists.

You will now learn the safety of the highlighted route.
Place the mouse over each street along route XGHJ.\n\nAs you move the mouse over each street, you will see the width, speed, and safety information of that street appear in the table below.

You should have discovered that along this route, only G Street is always safe for bikes. ALL streets along the route must be safe for bicyclists.\n\nLook at the list below of possible changes to the route. Some of the changes below will make the streets safer for bikes. Select all the changes that will make the street safer.
Click Table to review the width, speed, and safety information of all the streets along this route.
Increase the speed limit of J Street to 45 mph.
Increase the lane width of J Street to 14 feet.
Decrease the speed limit of H Street to 25 mph.
Increase the lane width of H Street to 14 feet.
Increase the speed limit of G Street to 45 mph.
Decrease the lane width of G Street to 13 feet.
Increase the lane width of X Street to 13 feet.

This is what the route would look like if all the necessary changes were made.

The cost to make the changes is shown in the lower left below the map.

Unfortunately, the town cannot afford to make these proposed changes.

You need to propose a different route connecting Pleasant Valley and Rolling Hills Park.

You will design your route by selecting roads on the map.

Click Tutorial to watch an animated demo showing how this tool works.

When you click on a street, it will be highlighted.

The street name, street length, and cost to change the street so that it is safe for bicycling will appear below the map.

Additional information about the speed limit and lane width of the street will also appear in a table.

Click Continue to go on.

Clicking on a second street will add the cost and length of the new street to the total cost at the bottom of the map.

Additional information about the second street will display in the table, and a new row will be added below to display the total selected route.

Click Continue to go on.
To change the route, click on a selected street again to deselect it. The totals and the table will be updated.

To change the route, click on a selected street again to deselect it. The totals and the table will be updated.

Then click on a new street. Information will change again at the bottom of the map and in the table below.

Click Next to set your own route or Back to review the tutorial.
